This was discussed at the stein PTG and got held up again on the owner type concept in placement:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-stein ~L243

If no one is working on the consumer type issue in placement, and this is not high enough priority for people to care about it, then I'd say we should probably just abandon the spec until someone cares enough to revive it and push this forward along with the dependencies."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-10-23 22:17:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I actually *do* care about this and want to see it done. I'm just kinda overwhelmed with internal Oath deployment stuff at the moment and can't see the end of the tunnel yet.

I'd like to get some of this work done in Stein, even if it's just partially complete to line things up for Train.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-10-23 22:22:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> This was discussed at the stein PTG and got held up again on the
 > owner type concept in placement:
 > 
 > https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-stein ~L243
 > 
 > If no one is working on the consumer type issue in placement, and
 > this is not high enough priority for people to care about it, then
 > I'd say we should probably just abandon the spec until someone
 > cares enough to revive it and push this forward along with the
 > dependencies.

I think it's important that we be able to count quota usage from placement because what we currently have is inefficient, especially when a project has a large amount of resources, particularly instances. But, this is held up on placement consumer type/owner, and given that placement development is currently frozen for placement extraction, that work isn't going to happen any time soon."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-23 22:26:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The placement extraction is not holding up other placement API changes from being proposed, so if that's the path we want to take eventually for consumer types, it could still be spec'ed up. If the placement extraction is what is holding this up, then why aren't more people helping with the placement extraction happening? It's just frustrating to see this stuff sitting here for nearly a year with no clear direction (or owner) and have people say it really matters to them."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-10-23 22:29:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > This was discussed at the stein PTG and got held up again on the
 > > owner type concept in placement:
 > >
 > > https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-stein ~L243
 > >
 > > If no one is working on the consumer type issue in placement, and
 > > this is not high enough priority for people to care about it,
 > then
 > > I'd say we should probably just abandon the spec until someone
 > > cares enough to revive it and push this forward along with the
 > > dependencies.
 > 
 > I think it's important that we be able to count quota usage from
 > placement because what we currently have is inefficient, especially
 > when a project has a large amount of resources, particularly
 > instances. But, this is held up on placement consumer type/owner,
 > and given that placement development is currently frozen for
 > placement extraction, that work isn't going to happen any time
 > soon.

To correct myself, I don't think placement would be more efficient at counting CPU and RAM because placement would also have to SUM over a table, same as we're doing now for instances vcpus and memory_mb columns. Sorry for adding noise on that.

The gain for this spec is to have quota usage counting ability unaffected by "down" cells.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-10-23 22:39:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> The placement extraction is not holding up other placement API
 > changes from being proposed, so if that's the path we want to take
 > eventually for consumer types, it could still be spec'ed up. If the
 > placement extraction is what is holding this up, then why aren't
 > more people helping with the placement extraction happening? It's
 > just frustrating to see this stuff sitting here for nearly a year
 > with no clear direction (or owner) and have people say it really
 > matters to them.

OK, I was under the impression that during the placement extraction, the nova and placement repos would accept bug fixes, but not changes to the APIs and new design work. Yes, I could write up a spec anyway, but I didn't think it would be helpful if API changes are on hold.

Well, as you know, we've discussed consumer type/owner multiple times over the past year, with no one agreeing on even a general direction to go. So, it's not easy to push this forward when every time I discuss it, there's no agreement or direction on how to accomplish it in placement. I share the feeling of frustration."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-10-23 22:43:46.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I'm going to abandon this for now, as efforts to solve the consumer type/owner gap in placement have not yet approached agreement and it's taking up space in the review backlog."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-10-24 00:09:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> The placement extraction is not holding up other placement API
 > changes from being proposed, so if that's the path we want to take
 > eventually for consumer types, it could still be spec'ed up. If the
 > placement extraction is what is holding this up, then why aren't
 > more people helping with the placement extraction happening? It's
 > just frustrating to see this stuff sitting here for nearly a year
 > with no clear direction (or owner) and have people say it really
 > matters to them.

You might be frustrated seeing this stuff sitting here for a year. I personally am incredibly frustrated with the seeming block-until-everything-is-perfect things we have going in nova right now. We could *easily* make *some* forward progress on this particular area if we didn't insist that every tiny detail be perfectly predicted and accurately handled in the spec.

For example, we could just agree to move forward with simple resource class accounting for quota using placement and say "sorry, multiple novas aren't supported right now, if you need that, keep using the existing quota functionality". And add the consumer type/source thing later on.

But it just seems everyone is bent on seeing perfect solutions spec'd up all the time instead of just plowing on with some code, seeing what works and what doesn't and fixing things as they arise.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-24 09:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> For example, we could just agree to move forward with simple
 > resource class accounting for quota using placement and say "sorry,
 > multiple novas aren't supported right now, if you need that, keep
 > using the existing quota functionality". And add the consumer
 > type/source thing later on.

Yeah, I've been wondering about this too. Presumably in an environment where quota limits are set somewhat globally and the placement service is only serving one cloud, being able to query for usage via /usage?project_id=blah&user_id=blap is sufficient to determine if someone is going to go over quota on the standard resource classes. I suspect I'm over simplifying things, but a) please educate me, b) maybe we should keep things simple for the first pass?

Satisfying just that use case would be a step forward for at least some people.

As far as "not being able to reach agreeement" on consumer type and sharding-key, we need to keep in mind that those are two different things. The former is to say "this is an instance allocation" the latter is "this is from cloud X". There's not a lot of agreement on the implementation of the latter (as there are several ways to accomplish it), but I think the resistance to implementing the former expired when we decided to create consumer objects and tables in placement. Or at least mine did.

What we did agree at the PTG was that doing consumer/quota-related work wasn't highest priority. Getting real working nested was and the expectation was (and still appears to be the case) that that was going to eat up both coding and review time heartily as we discover corner cases.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-10-24 17:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> For example, we could just agree to move forward with simple
 > resource class accounting for quota using placement and say "sorry,
 > multiple novas aren't supported right now, if you need that, keep
 > using the existing quota functionality". And add the consumer
 > type/source thing later on.

I definitely agree that we could make some progress on using placement for this stuff without everything worked out. However, the multiple novas thing is not a minor detail to me, especially after the recent edge session in Denver where people are clearly planning to use multiple novas against a common set of control services (which would include placement). If we just figure we'll do that in the future, then we'll have a migration like we did for consumers which has to touch every provider and I think we should try to avoid that, knowing it will come.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-10-25 01:08:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > For example, we could just agree to move forward with simple
 > > resource class accounting for quota using placement and say
 > "sorry,
 > > multiple novas aren't supported right now, if you need that, keep
 > > using the existing quota functionality". And add the consumer
 > > type/source thing later on.
 > 
 > Yeah, I've been wondering about this too. Presumably in an
 > environment where quota limits are set somewhat globally and the
 > placement service is only serving one cloud, being able to query
 > for usage via /usage?project_id=blah&user_id=blap is sufficient to
 > determine if someone is going to go over quota on the standard
 > resource classes. I suspect I'm over simplifying things, but a)
 > please educate me, b) maybe we should keep things simple for the
 > first pass?
 > 
 > Satisfying just that use case would be a step forward for at least
 > some people.
 > 
 > As far as "not being able to reach agreeement" on consumer type and
 > sharding-key, we need to keep in mind that those are two different
 > things. The former is to say "this is an instance allocation" the
 > latter is "this is from cloud X". There's not a lot of agreement on
 > the implementation of the latter (as there are several ways to
 > accomplish it), but I think the resistance to implementing the
 > former expired when we decided to create consumer objects and
 > tables in placement. Or at least mine did.
 
OK, that's fair enough. Apologies for not thinking as deeply as I should have when I kept saying "consumer type" because that's actually and unfortunately not enough. In a world (the EDGE™ world) where multiple novas will be using the same placement, we'll need partitioning for the standard resource classes. We'll need to know they came from nova X or nova Y (nova X wants to know its own /usages). And that edge world is rapidly approaching.

I think Dan's point about dealing with a data migration is compelling. But I'm a bit confused about, how is the migration worse if we go ahead and count quota usage from placement now? Placement already contains lots of consumers and allocations. When we introduce the concept of partitioning, won't we have to do something/the same thing to migrate all of those existing records regardless of whether we go ahead and count quota usage from placement today?

The main bad thing I can think of if we were to go ahead with calling /usages today is that anyone who wants to use multiple novas with one placement for an edge deployment will have broken quota handling and there would be no recourse for them. And that's pretty major.

 > What we did agree at the PTG was that doing consumer/quota-related
 > work wasn't highest priority. Getting real working nested was and
 > the expectation was (and still appears to be the case) that that
 > was going to eat up both coding and review time heartily as we
 > discover corner cases.

This is true. The quota behavior in the presence of down cells is important but we have a plan for getting by. And like you said, getting real working nested is more important, especially given that we do have a "get by" plan. There are just too many important things. All I meant to say in my earlier comments here are that this is important, but I think it is less important than the things we already have on our full plates.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-10-25 14:27:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I think Dan's point about dealing with a data migration is
 > compelling. But I'm a bit confused about, how is the migration
 > worse if we go ahead and count quota usage from placement now?
 > Placement already contains lots of consumers and allocations. When
 > we introduce the concept of partitioning, won't we have to do
 > something/the same thing to migrate all of those existing records
 > regardless of whether we go ahead and count quota usage from
 > placement today?

That's a fair point, and something we can make a call on. I think the major reason not to proceed without solving that is that it increases the delay between introducing the fix and being able to use it. There will have to be a cycle where we do the data migration, and either a cycle (or signal) where nova starts querying by partitioning key, and after that, a second nova could be introduced. The sooner we start that process the less complex and time-consuming the sequence is.

 > The main bad thing I can think of if we were to go ahead with
 > calling /usages today is that anyone who wants to use multiple
 > novas with one placement for an edge deployment will have broken
 > quota handling and there would be no recourse for them. And that's
 > pretty major.

And Jay mentioned something that implied we'd keep the old quota mechanism around for people that need this, which I also think is pretty major. We moved to placement in what, Ocata, and we still haven't been able to deprecate and remove alllll the old school resource tracker stuff because we're still allowing  people to be running with the caching scheduler which requires it. I'd like to not repeat that for quotas, personally."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-11-14 15:26:30.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

Belmiro asked me about counting quota usage from placement today, so restoring this with a proposal on how to handle the lack of placement partitioning support in the meantime.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-11-14 15:29:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-11-15 09:54:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-20 21:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Seems reasonable to me. Gets some useful functionality without having to change placement immediately, which is probably sensible given the current flux.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-11-20 22:08:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

I just want to say that I'm disappointed that we have to do the config thing and keep all the existing code because we're hamstrung on the placement partitioning thing. Right now there is an edge reference architecture that would suffer from not being able to count quotas with a central placement, and which also would suffer major scheduling performance issues during boot, because we'd get back placement results from providers in other Novas which we'd have to forcibly filter out against our list of compute nodes.

We're also introducing an upgrade requirement which is that if and when we do move to a partitioned placement, all novas have to be upgraded and that data has to be migrated before the feature(s) that depend on it (scheduling and quota currently) can be enabled. That's something we'll have to remember to document when that time comes.

Whining aside, comments inline."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-20 23:00:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> I just want to say that I'm disappointed that we have to do the
 > config thing and keep all the existing code because we're hamstrung
 > on the placement partitioning thing.

We don't _have_ to be hamstrung on doing the partitioning thing. We could choose to do it but we'd probably have to toss something else. However, I was under the impression from the PTG that we had decided that neither partitioning and quota counting was highest priority. Obviously, times can change and often do, but if they are we need to make room in the nest."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-11-21 20:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-11-21 21:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > I just want to say that I'm disappointed that we have to do the
 > > config thing and keep all the existing code because we're
 > hamstrung
 > > on the placement partitioning thing.
 > 
 > We don't _have_ to be hamstrung on doing the partitioning thing. We
 > could choose to do it but we'd probably have to toss something
 > else. However, I was under the impression from the PTG that we had
 > decided that neither partitioning and quota counting was highest
 > priority. Obviously, times can change and often do, but if they are
 > we need to make room in the nest.

Your impression was correct, partitioning and/or quota counting was not a high priority compared to other things.

In this case, times changed [unfortunately]. I had thought the workaround (policy-driven fail or allow) was going to be "OK" with operators but have since been enlightened that the workaround is not really "OK" and will cause significant pain. Thusly, I am trying to find support in this spec with minimal (IMHO, one counting method) debt to carry forward until we have placement partitioning. Placement partitioning is not going to be an easy task and is not something I realistically think we can or should rush through to avoid carrying one method of debt. Just MHO.

So, my thinking here is go forward with this small debt in Stein and get partitioning on the placement roadmap as soon as we can, in T or U.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-11-21 21:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2018-11-22 15:48:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

I'm OK and +1 with the workaround config option proposed because it will improve dramatically nova availability when using multiple cells.

However, I fail to see the real value of having a placement service for multiple nova deployments. Placement will become a single point of failure for multiple nova deployments. But considering that partitions are really required for edge, why can't we explicitly have the requirement of having a placement per nova until partitions are ready? Currently (without partitions) running a placement for multiple nova deployments must be extremely inefficient."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-11-26 15:09:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

> But considering that
 > partitions are really required for edge, why can't we explicitly
 > have the requirement of having a placement per nova until
 > partitions are ready? Currently (without partitions) running a
 > placement for multiple nova deployments must be extremely
 > inefficient.

We can (and obviously will), but the problem is also that it's not just nova. In a single site where you're trying to be thin on control services, the problem also arises when multiple things want to use placement where resource classes overlap. Something like standalone ironic in the same site, or even something like magnum that could start using placement would conflict. My problem with it is that it becomes an invisible failure that will be really (really) hard to figure out once it happens. Nova will just start returning over quota for a tenant with very few resources, and there won't be a quick path out of that problem situation. It's definitely a future thing at this point, I'm just worried that if we don't cleanly partition now, before we start using placement like this, that the point at which it will become an acute problem will be late and "new code" and "migrate every item of data" will be the only path out.

However, I think it's pretty clear that I'm in the minority here, so you need not worry :)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-12-05 00:25:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)

It's a fine plan. ++

I personally think we shouldn't be jumping through hoops to continue supporting user-specific quotas, however. In Denver, there wasn't a single operator who said they used that functionality, and now that Keystone has project hierarchies and will be able to return the limits for a sub-project accurately, I don't see the need to continue supporting user-specific quotas. But, that might be too much change for Nova to handle and the small change required by this spec to continue supporting user-specific quotas (the addition of the user_id field to the instance_mappings) table is acceptable I guess.

I'll leave the final vote to Dan.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-01-07 21:06:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > It's a fine plan. ++
 > 
 > I personally think we shouldn't be jumping through hoops to
 > continue supporting user-specific quotas, however. In Denver, there
 > wasn't a single operator who said they used that functionality, and
 > now that Keystone has project hierarchies and will be able to
 > return the limits for a sub-project accurately, I don't see the
 > need to continue supporting user-specific quotas. But, that might
 > be too much change for Nova to handle and the small change required
 > by this spec to continue supporting user-specific quotas (the
 > addition of the user_id field to the instance_mappings) table is
 > acceptable I guess.
 > 
 > I'll leave the final vote to Dan.
 > 
 > -jay

Thank you for the review. You're right that we do want to drop user-specific quotas in the future, but the plan (IIUC) was to do that as part of our migration to keystone limits + oslo.limit, as keystone limits don't support user-specific limits (and have strict two-level hierarchy ability instead).

I can sympathize with your desire not to jump through hoops to support user-specific quota, but the only hoop here is a small one, which is adding the user_id column to the instance_mappings table. It would be a lot more work for me to remove user-specific quotas along with this spec and it feels like that in itself would be its own spec with how involved the change would be (plus it would need a new API microversion). And maybe it would also need a deprecation period before removal.

I also thought, since instances have a project/user ownership, it seems fitting that instance mappings would have project/user available as well. But I understand we haven't needed user_id on instance mappings yet, until now."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-01-07 21:20:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

 > that as part of our migration to keystone limits + oslo.limit, as
 > keystone limits don't support user-specific limits (and have strict
 > two-level hierarchy ability instead).

Well, in keystone we support a couple of models, one of which is a completely flat hierarchy. The other is a strict two-level hierarchy that has more opinions about the flow of resources between projects in a "tree". The flat model doesn't have opinions about how resources flow between projects but is likely more cumbersome for operators to manage (at the expense that they have all the control they need to do whatever they want with resource limits - whether or not what they do adheres to the project hierarchy, if they have one, is up to them.)

I don't think either model will help with respect to user-specific quota. In Denver, I remember coming to the conclusion that user-specific one-offs would be kept in the service, and services could leverage keystone for project-specific limits on consumable resources.

[{'created': '2017-10-03 01:51:53.000000000', 'message': "Propose counting quota usage from placement

In Pike, we re-architected the quota system to count actual resource
usage instead of using reservations and tracking quota usages in a
separate database table. We're counting resources like instances, CPU,
and RAM by querying each cell database and aggregating the results per
project and per user. This approach has a couple of downsides: it is
not too efficient and it is susceptible to undesirable behavior if a
cell becomes unavailable. If a cell becomes unavailable, resources in
its database cannot be counted and will not be included in resource
usage until the cell returns. Cells could become unavailable if an
operator is performing maintenance on a cell or if a cell database is
experiencing problems and we cannot connect to it.

We can make resource usage counting for quotas much more efficient and
resilient to temporary cell outages by querying placement for resource
usage instead of reading separate cell databases.

Change-Id: Ib86a7994d7a577b8e6a2dd32f4fcf12b7f788af8

commit_message:
Propose counting quota usage from placement and API database

In Pike, we re-architected the quota system to count actual resource
usage instead of using reservations and tracking quota usages in a
separate database table. We're counting resources like instances, CPU,
and RAM by querying each cell database and aggregating the results per
project and per user. This approach is susceptible to undesirable
behavior if a cell becomes unavailable. If a cell becomes unavailable,
resources in its database cannot be counted and will not be included in
resource usage until the cell returns. Cells could become unavailable
if an operator is performing maintenance on a cell or if a cell
database is experiencing problems and we cannot connect to it.

We can make resource usage counting for quotas resilient to temporary
cell outages by querying placement and the API database for resource
usage instead of reading separate cell databases.

Spec for blueprint count-quota-usage-from-placement

Change-Id: Ib86a7994d7a577b8e6a2dd32f4fcf12b7f788af8

commit_message:
Only cap pylint for python2

I noticed that pylint environment doesn't work with Python 3.7; I
guess the pinned version has become incompatible.  From the history
the pin is only for Python 2.7 compatability, so just restrict it to
that (with the basepython for the environment set to python3, it's
questionable if we still support pylint with 2.7, but anyway).

Change-Id: I6a916c8422239a4e1b47dcf28a4569f1637cae7a

[{'created': '2019-01-09 13:53:42.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround for installing correct version of ruby bundler

See https://github.com/bundler/bundler/issues/6870

Bundler 2.x dropped support for Ruby < 2.3 so now we detect ruby
version and install last known to work version.

This means that newer OS will get newer versions of bundler.

Change-Id: I906ad01187ad5b929b378107de065d32d23c5fc2
Closes-Bug: #1810401
(cherry picked from commit 7acca40563ebde1696a95a4ab9f646b754edeeb2)
'}]
commit_message:
Workaround for installing correct version of ruby bundler

See https://github.com/bundler/bundler/issues/6870

Bundler 2.x dropped support for Ruby < 2.3 so now we detect ruby
version and install last known to work version.

This means that newer OS will get newer versions of bundler.

Change-Id: I906ad01187ad5b929b378107de065d32d23c5fc2
Closes-Bug: #1810401
(cherry picked from commit 7acca40563ebde1696a95a4ab9f646b754edeeb2)

While the common exceptions have already been rehomed into neutron-lib

to neutron.common.exceptions. This patch syncs them by rehoming those

Change-Id: I10f6bf2d62c95613627101c3fdd7c9cb98d494db
'}]
commit_message:
sync neutron.common.exceptions into neutron-lib

While the common exceptions have already been rehomed into neutron-lib
[1] and have been shimmed in neutron [2], folks continue to add them
to neutron.common.exceptions. This patch syncs them by rehoming those
that have been added to neutron after the fact.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/319328/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/586525/

Change-Id: I10f6bf2d62c95613627101c3fdd7c9cb98d494db

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-09 14:45:44.000000000', 'message': 'Initiating Cinder Volume Manager with large number of volumes

This patch adds the option to split retrieved volumes and snapshots
by chunks during Volume Manager host initialization. Query results
will be obtained in batches from the database and not in one shot
to avoid extreme memory usage. Max number of volumes and snapshots
per batch is controlled by option init_host_max_objects_retrieval.
Option is disabled by default for backward compatibility.

To migrate any ConfKeyManager keys based on fixed_key to the currently
configured key manager Volume Manager will use special lightweight
object - VolumeMigration.

Change-Id: I53eccc77fdc2c35b27ed430af62dc18e7d1bde69
Closes-Bug: 1681374
'}, {'created': '2019-01-09 22:02:44.000000000', 'message': 'Initiating Cinder Volume Manager with large number of volumes

by chunks during Volume Manager host initialization. Query results
will be obtained in batches from the database and not in one shot
to avoid extreme memory usage. Max number of volumes and snapshots
per batch is controlled by option init_host_max_objects_retrieval.
Option is disabled by default for backward compatibility.

To migrate any ConfKeyManager keys based on fixed_key to the currently
configured key manager Volume Manager will use special lightweight
object - VolumeMigration.

Change-Id: I53eccc77fdc2c35b27ed430af62dc18e7d1bde69
Closes-Bug: 1681374
(cherry picked from commit 5b08390b9d203a32892a6424576eee5a5a5f0bc8)
'}]
commit_message:
Initiating Cinder Volume Manager with large number of volumes

This patch adds the option to split retrieved volumes and snapshots
by chunks during Volume Manager host initialization. Query results
will be obtained in batches from the database and not in one shot
to avoid extreme memory usage. Max number of volumes and snapshots
per batch is controlled by option init_host_max_objects_retrieval.
Option is disabled by default for backward compatibility.

To migrate any ConfKeyManager keys based on fixed_key to the currently
configured key manager Volume Manager will use special lightweight
object - VolumeMigration.

Change-Id: I53eccc77fdc2c35b27ed430af62dc18e7d1bde69
Closes-Bug: 1681374
(cherry picked from commit 5b08390b9d203a32892a6424576eee5a5a5f0bc8)

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

commit_message:
Add horizon WebSSO support for OpenID Connect

This adds support for configuring horizon for WebSSO when keystone
federation with OpenID Connect is enabled.  This patch just exposes
some new parameters to use puppet-horizon for configuration.  The
sample environment file for OpenID Connect federation is also updated
to use the new parameters.  Some of the sample defaults were updated
to more closely match the URLs that horizon expects.

Change-Id: I7c3ee6b54cc0c9653742c3ce1de60b2851d1fe68

subject: APIv2 - Fix 500 on malformed query string on
messages:
[{'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-06 19:53:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-06 21:34:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-06 21:37:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-07 12:29:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-10 11:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-10 16:22:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-12-11 12:14:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Given the amount of pdb occurrences in the code, should it be considered still WIP? 

Will the change only affect v2?'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-11 12:53:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Given the amount of pdb occurrences in the code, should it be
 > considered still WIP?
 > 
 > Will the change only affect v2?

The pdb was a mistake on my side. IIRC the change should be done on API v1 as well, because since it is an unintentional return error, we can still fix it. Not sure, what do you think it is best?'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-12-11 13:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> > Given the amount of pdb occurrences in the code, should it be
 > > considered still WIP?
 > >
 > > Will the change only affect v2?
 > 
 > The pdb was a mistake on my side. IIRC the change should be done on
 > API v1 as well, because since it is an unintentional return error,
 > we can still fix it. Not sure, what do you think it is best?

There was a long and complicated debate which involved at least QA and api-wg on whether changing the return code of an API breaks the API backward compatibility. 

The change towards 5xx seems to break it, according:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/api_interoperability.html

so I would keep APIv1 as it is.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-11 13:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-12-12 06:05:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This is on the right track (minus some confusion, which might only be my own confusion).

But it doesn't quite fix everything, for example:
- POST /jobs/<id> allows "refresh_status" in the query string
- So, it would seem "refresh_status" should be in the whitelist
- But if it's in the whitelist, it will break calls like [1] because the underlying SQL query will still throw an error due to unexpected stuff in get_request_args
- Therefore we need a different a specific whitelist for each call

It may be possible to write an elegant decorator to express and record the mapping between API calls and allowed query string values. (Or the mapping could be expressed/recorded in a different way, just a suggestion.)


[1] https://github.com/openstack/sahara/blob/90ca15859e50dc83d80d9411e86a7983ca6914b9/sahara/api/v2/data_sources.py#L33'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-12 10:45:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-12-12 17:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

oh, interesting, thank you for the explanation.

can you send me a link to that client stuff?'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-12 17:19:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> oh, interesting, thank you for the explanation.
 > 
 > can you send me a link to that client stuff?

Actually I'm double checking that information. I will get back to you."}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-12 20:27:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-12 20:53:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-13 14:33:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-12-19 19:11:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Also, shouldn't we wrap every API function with the decorator? Strict checking is good for everything..."}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-12-31 17:14:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-01-02 17:07:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Where does the request param 'long' come from?"}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2019-01-03 13:41:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I got that from the running the openstack dataprocessing ....'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2019-01-09 18:44:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> I got that from the running the openstack dataprocessing ....

Jeremy, did you get a chance to look into this? if the long is really a parameter?'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-01-09 18:49:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> > I got that from the running the openstack dataprocessing ....
 > 
 > Jeremy, did you get a chance to look into this? if the long is
 > really a parameter?

It's not a parameter as far as I can tell. It doesn't appear in the sahara api code and when I try to use it I get an error. So let's take it out."}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2019-01-09 18:52:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-01-09 19:04:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2

(4 comments)

Looks good to me.
I'll address my observation in a follow-up patch."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-01-09 21:00:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
APIv2 - Fix 500 on malformed query string on

In order to improve return information to clients we are adding a check
to verify parameters before each call and return a more appropriate
message to the users.

Change-Id: I9923601d0903e415a3fe30bec9bdc8fc34b91ff6
Story: #2004506

commit_message:
Set paramiko logging to DEBUG level

Connections to backends via paramiko often fail for obscure
reasons.

If the service log level is DEBUG, increase paramiko logging
to DEBUG level as well so that we have more information when issues
of this sort occur.

Change-Id: I44d8902d58c2ad48b8a37dfbff96c5b9471651e4

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-30 03:37:50.000000000', 'message': 'Change ssh_utils parameter to correctly sends keepalive packets

The current implementation of ssh_utils never sends keepalive packets.
In ssh_utils.SSHPool, the socket timeout parameter is set to None
intending to keep ssh connections open.
However, when the parameter is set to None, ssh_utils does not run the
code to compare idle duration and keepalive interval.

This patch reverts the socket timeout parameter to default (0.1 sec).
The ssh_utils compares them every 0.1 seconds, and sends a keepalive
packet if idle duration > keepalive interval (= self.conn_timeout).

See cinder change: I8234083107207b9ebc0849947e8de92b5cf3e36e

Change-Id: Ib13e5c6246412d667554cb0bd9c419b513af70c7
Related-Bug: #1673662
'}, {'created': '2018-12-30 17:25:50.000000000', 'message': 'Change ssh_utils parameter to correctly sends keepalive packets

commit_message:
Change ssh_utils parameter to correctly send keepalive packets

The current implementation of ssh_utils never sends keepalive packets.
In ssh_utils.SSHPool, the socket timeout parameter is set to None
intending to keep ssh connections open.
However, when the parameter is set to None, ssh_utils does not run the
code to compare idle duration and keepalive interval.

This patch reverts the socket timeout parameter to default (0.1 sec).
The ssh_utils compares them every 0.1 seconds, and sends a keepalive
packet if idle duration > keepalive interval (= self.conn_timeout).

See cinder change: I8234083107207b9ebc0849947e8de92b5cf3e36e

Change-Id: Ib13e5c6246412d667554cb0bd9c419b513af70c7
Related-Bug: #1673662

commit_message:
WIP: Keep reference to CFUNCTYPE callback object

As mentioned in:
https://docs.python.org/2/library/ctypes.html#callback-functions

Try keeping a reference to the netlink callback method so
it's not garbage collected, possibly causing a segfault.

Change-Id: I1524f4b47ee33e9416c12c4824f82b2d7d399958

commit_message:
Remove built-in plugins from database schema

Add an alembic migration to remove the built-in plugins. Monasca-notification
becomes responsible for creating them, if they are enabled in the
monasca-notification config file. This also adds some very basic tests and
fixes an issue with Python 3 support (highlighted by the tests) where the
schema was stored as unicode which prevented hashing.

Story: 2003801
Task: 26533
Change-Id: I74848bac2137e446c8825f23778f6a16a96a2048

commit_message:
Update GPG signing key for Grafana

The signing key has changed. Packagecloud has moved to using per-project
GPG keys and has migrated all old projects off the global signing key as
of January 7[1]. The global signing key is no longer useful.

[1]: https://blog.packagecloud.io/eng/2018/10/17/gpg-key-migration/

Change-Id: Icc987948e4bca301b52a8b11f58d2aab711cdef5
Closes-Bug: #1810867

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-21 16:43:15.000000000', 'message': "runner: run inspect quietly

When we run:
  $ podman inspect --type image --format exists <image>

Against a non-existing image, we end up with message like:
  error getting image <image>: unable to find <image> in local storage
  unable to find a name and tag match for <image> in repotags

It is not an error for us, since we use inspect to test if an image does
exist or not, and then action based on results. So we don't really want
the error message in the logs, and confuse our operators.

This patch will make the inspect command quiet so we don't display the
error message anymore.

Change-Id: Ie16ca7377e8e5e5c63d9630cf6d26e0bc8df6b1a
Related: https://github.com/containers/libpod/issues/1845
"}, {'created': '2018-11-23 13:35:35.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: runner: test if image exists before running inspect

TODO: add unit tests.

When we run:
  $ podman inspect --type image --format exists <image>

Against a non-existing image, we end up with message like:
  error getting image <image>: unable to find <image> in local storage
  unable to find a name and tag match for <image> in repotags

Podman will have a command called:
  $ podman images exist <image>"

Which would return 0 or 1.
So before running the inspect command, we verify that the image
actually exists.
If the container CMD is Podman, the new function will test that the
image exists and if not the inspect won't run. No change for Docker as
the command isn't implemented in it.

Change-Id: Ie16ca7377e8e5e5c63d9630cf6d26e0bc8df6b1a
Related: https://github.com/containers/libpod/issues/1845
'}, {'created': '2018-11-23 13:39:58.000000000', 'message': "WIP: runner: test if image exists before running inspect

When we run:

Against a non-existing image, we end up with message like:

The messages can confuse the operators, and we don't want that.

commit_message:
runner: test if image exists before running inspect

When we run:
  $ podman inspect --type image --format exists <image>

Against a non-existing image, we end up with message like:
  error getting image <image>: unable to find <image> in local storage
  unable to find a name and tag match for <image> in repotags

The messages can confuse the operators, and we don't want that.

Podman will have a command called:
  $ podman image exists <image>

Which would return 0 if the image actually exists.
So before running the inspect command, we verify that the image
actually exists.
If the container CMD is Podman, the new function will test that the
image exists and if not the inspect won't run. No change for Docker as
the command isn't implemented in it.

Change-Id: Ie16ca7377e8e5e5c63d9630cf6d26e0bc8df6b1a
Related: https://github.com/containers/libpod/issues/1845

commit_message:
Set API version in RestClient

Tempest (at least this area of it) needs to be explicitly told which
version of the Sahara API to use, if the URL in the catalog isn't
already versioned. So, set a certain class property to convince
Tempest to append the API version to the base URL.

Change-Id: I5066f73aa0ace79d8d5e1431f8d741d0d942d9d5

Bump, this is still required to ensure that unstack happens after running tempest'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2019-01-09 20:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I believe the intent of this functionality was to support functional testing of software that only needed devstack to isntall the software and not run it or test it. Then the followup tooling was responsible for starting processes and testing it.

The problem with this chagne and that use case is now you will have extra unexpected processes running potentially bound to ports preventing your sofwtare from being tested properly.

One approach may be to use a different flag indicating where you want things to be torn down.'}]

commit_message:
Move location of devstack-gate unstack to post-tempest

Setting DEVSTACK_GATE_UNSTACK currently will cause devstack-gate to
unstack devstack prior to running tempest. This patch moves that logic
into a EXIT trap to ensure it always runs after everything else is done.
So that it works for environments where they need to stack, run some
tests, and then unstack. This is extremely useful for CI environments
when a test slave must be reused.

Change-Id: I5cc7a759537cf62781c534890260df440ed6ea7b

Sphinx 1.6 deprecated using the application object to perform logging
and it will be removed in the upcoming 2.0 release. This updates our
extensions to use the recommended sphinx.util.logging instead.

Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Update sphinx extension logging

Sphinx 1.6 deprecated using the application object to perform logging
and it will be removed in the upcoming 2.0 release. This updates our
extensions to use the recommended sphinx.util.logging instead.

Change-Id: I083f4debaa16d3bc2a3388bbb33c718b473563ef
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-08 20:21:42.000000000', 'message': "Reno only - Check for available networks for a role

Since change: I07822ec0cba7eed352c0010eb893b5e5a522e95c
resources are no longer created for networks that are not
defined in roles data. While this is an improvement we
need to communicate this change.

There is tribal knowledge and documentation that failed
reflect the requirement to add networks to roles data
since the introduction of composable networks in Pike.

Prior to Pike adding a network to a role was achived by
overriding the resource_registry entry to not use the
noop.yaml fake port (fall back to ctlplane) template.
i.e to add External network to compute role the
following was commonly added to network-environment.yaml

  OS::TripleO::Compute::Ports::ExternalPort:
    ../network/ports/external.yaml

NOTE: Current OVN-DVR and ODL doc's downstream uses the
      resource_registry override, whitout also adding
      the network to roles data.

Related-Bug: #1800811
Change-Id: I6c03c7a2bd6f369bf35a9e479a97302c9a455197
(cherry picked from commit 991e0fc0c0c9fc24b53b3760b396de75d9fb52ad)
"}]
commit_message:
Reno only - Check for available networks for a role

Since change: I07822ec0cba7eed352c0010eb893b5e5a522e95c
resources are no longer created for networks that are not
defined in roles data. While this is an improvement we
need to communicate this change.

There is tribal knowledge and documentation that failed
reflect the requirement to add networks to roles data
since the introduction of composable networks in Pike.

Prior to Pike adding a network to a role was achived by
overriding the resource_registry entry to not use the
noop.yaml fake port (fall back to ctlplane) template.
i.e to add External network to compute role the
following was commonly added to network-environment.yaml

  OS::TripleO::Compute::Ports::ExternalPort:
    ../network/ports/external.yaml

NOTE: Current OVN-DVR and ODL doc's downstream uses the
      resource_registry override, whitout also adding
      the network to roles data.

Related-Bug: #1800811
Change-Id: I6c03c7a2bd6f369bf35a9e479a97302c9a455197
(cherry picked from commit 991e0fc0c0c9fc24b53b3760b396de75d9fb52ad)

The changes related to ceph look reasonable.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-11-13 14:12:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

With the defaults in the scenario001 job it seems to have produced a valid ceph.conf [1] with a working ceph cluster [2][3]. It looks like the CI is not yet exercising a routed network scenario (at least for ceph). The ceph.conf for scenario004 is good too [4] as well as the ceph-ansible run [5]. It looks like if the NetCidrMapValue contains a list storing the cidr of each subnet for each network,. that it should work. I've already verified elsewhere that you can pass '"public_network": "172.17.4.0/24, 172.18.4.0/24, 172.19.4.0/24"' to ceph-ansible to produce a working ceph cluster. Certainly no problem here with the Ceph change as far as I'm concerned. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-11-13 14:13:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

 > NetCidrMapValue contains a list storing the cidr of each subnet for
 > each network,. that it should work. I've already verified elsewhere
 > that you can pass '"public_network": "172.17.4.0/24, 172.18.4.0/24,
 > 172.19.4.0/24"' to ceph-ansible to produce a working ceph cluster.
 > Certainly no problem here with the Ceph change as far as I'm
 > concerned. Thanks.

commit_message:
Make NetCidrMapValue contain list of cidrs in each net

Prior to routed networks we only had one subnet per network.
With routed networks each network can have multiple subnets.
The NetCidrMapValue should contain a list storing the cidr
of each subnet for each network.

Ceph:
  list_join is used to make a comma separated list of
  cidrs for public_network, monitor_address_block,
  cluster_network and radosgw_address_block.

Partial: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-templates
Depends-On: Ia8e219b30d4f8b199b882e95fe2834252a92c15a
Depends-On: I1ace0a02e6aa2610559fee0d8576e6f1bc98d699

commit_message:
Fix testing for the write-devstack-local-conf role

The test_plugin_deps function in the test code for the
write-devstack-local-conf role was missing the import part of actually
executing the code under test and asserting the expected result.

Change-Id: I125870b13d2581cdec0dede11157b19b702565cd

commit_message:
install under python3 by default when enabled

Remove the requirement that services explicitly enable python3 support
in order to be tested under python3 when running with python3
enabled. Keep the enable_python3_package() function for backwards
compatibility, for now, since it is called in some devstack plugins.

Explicitly add swift to the set of packages that should not be installed
using python3 by default until full support is available.

Change-Id: I8ab0a7c242bbf5bf3f091f5a85a98e2f4543f856
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-25 11:31:57.000000000', 'message': 'Extract copy_image_to_volume into volume utils

The "_copy_image_to_volume" method is a common function to
copy image to volume.

commit_message:
Extract copy_image_to_volume into volume utils

The "_copy_image_to_volume" method is a common function to
copy image to volume.

This also can be used by re-image interface, this patch
extract them into volume utils.

part of blueprint: add-volume-re-image-api

Change-Id: I89471fd2737d0b21ce029a6ad7ed43a6e8bf4810

(1 comment)

The intent seems less than obvious here, at less on the second thought. Although, it may be because of my poor English. Is a validator something that verifies that a thing is valid, or makes a thing valid?

Also, I wish there was a sample for the middleware. In particular, what is supposed to happen when two middlewares in the pipeline desire to set up this hook? They need to chain it somehow, right?'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-10-16 19:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

> Is a validator something that verifies that a thing is valid, or makes a thing valid?

The first one -- I ought to come up with a better name. slo_manifest_hook maybe?

> In particular, what is supposed to happen when two middlewares in the pipeline desire to set up this hook? They need to chain it somehow, right?

So far, the only two use-cases I know of would be mutually exclusive: s3api and tlo. In the general case, though, yeah -- we may want them to pick up a reference to the original callback and chain calls. I think we can do that after the fact and as needed, though, similar to how https://review.openstack.org/#/c/586902/ is adding chaining for multiple keymasters.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-10-18 00:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add slo_manifest_hook callback

... to allow other middlewares to impose additional constraints on
or make edits to SLO manifests before being written.

The callback takes a single argument: the python list that represents
the manifest to be written. All the normal list operations listed at
https://docs.python.org/2/library/stdtypes.html#mutable-sequence-types
are available to make changes to that before SLO serializes it as JSON.

The callback may return a list of problematic segments; each item in the
list should be a tuple of

    (quoted object name, description of problem)

This will be useful both for s3api minimum segment size validation and
creating tar large objects.

Change-Id: I198c5196e0221a72b14597a06e5ce3c4b2bbf436
Related-Bug: #1636663

+1 for using better default values. i wasn't sure if those options are related to any STIG documents. the 'offline' option was the initial motivation for my change"}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-01-09 18:40:10.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-07 21:59:24.000000000', 'message': "ntp: fix pool options

This patch drops the offline option because this role usually
applies to always-on machines and the subsystem which detects
if you're online or offline seems to be largely unstable which
causes chronyd to never attempt to synchronize time.

It also drops the minpoll and maxpoll options to leave it to
the defaults of the chronyd service, this is due to the numbers
provided not allowing the system to properly sync up time.

It also adds the 'iburst' option which will send a few quick
bursts when the system first goes up in order to get it to sync
up with time faster.

Change-Id: Ibb5309897b2d3e22102a06c8d87e4709785850d3
"}]
commit_message:
ntp: fix pool options

This patch drops the offline option because this role usually
applies to always-on machines and the subsystem which detects
if you're online or offline seems to be largely unstable which
causes chronyd to never attempt to synchronize time.

It also drops the minpoll and maxpoll options to leave it to
the defaults of the chronyd service, this is due to the numbers
provided not allowing the system to properly sync up time.

It also adds the 'iburst' option which will send a few quick
bursts when the system first goes up in order to get it to sync
up with time faster.

Change-Id: Ibb5309897b2d3e22102a06c8d87e4709785850d3

commit_message:
Set clustered when resources are configured

Primary charms can react on the clustered=True relation setting. Set
this value when a sufficient number of peers are available and the
resources are running on this node.

Change-Id: Ia935730145a56a1b8f9c351681eb6c8eb95f697e
Closes-Bug: #1749280

When hacluster is related gate client calls till the underlying
corosync cluster is ready and sets cluster=True on the relation.

Previously, only the leader was gated as the test was nested in a
leader check. This change guarantees clients are not updated until
corosync is ready.

Change-Id: I4bddedbaa230e9a4bb83008b2c86b51ce2605eb0
Closes-Bug: #1749280
'}]
commit_message:
Gate on hacluster relation setting clustered

When hacluster is related gate client calls till the underlying
corosync cluster is ready and sets cluster=True on the relation.

Previously, only the leader was gated as the test was nested in a
leader check. This change guarantees clients are not updated until
corosync is ready.

Change-Id: I4bddedbaa230e9a4bb83008b2c86b51ce2605eb0
Closes-Bug: #1749280

commit_message:
Implement generic representor offload port profile

* This change renames the VIFPortProfileOVSRepresentor class to
  VIFPortProfileRepresentor

* In order to support offloads on more datapaths, it was decided to
  rename and repurpose the OVS specific class to be more generic.

* This implementation is detailed as "Option 2" in the
  generic-os-vif-offloads spec.

Change-Id: Icc9cad1ab4edda5cc2bbb2b8f43678f2de516920
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>

commit_message:
Add retry to `nvme connect` in nvme connector

It is noticed that there could be some delays for a successful `nvme
connect` after "initialize_connection()" is completed in Cinder RSD
driver.

So add retries here, while keep the original logic intact.

Change-Id: I049f1d701c99612959d8262342aa63a043a97db0

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-09 14:02:38.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround for installing correct version of ruby bundler

See https://github.com/bundler/bundler/issues/6870

Bundler 2.x dropped support for Ruby < 2.3 so now we detect ruby
version and install last known to work version. This means that
newer OS will get newer versions of bundler.

Closes-Bug: #1810401
  (cherry picked from commit 7acca40563ebde1696a95a4ab9f646b754edeeb2)

Change-Id: Ibd1ff419d13cace906d4cd9765dc7b5486bc19a7
'}]
commit_message:
Workaround for installing correct version of ruby bundler

See https://github.com/bundler/bundler/issues/6870

Bundler 2.x dropped support for Ruby < 2.3 so now we detect ruby
version and install last known to work version. This means that
newer OS will get newer versions of bundler.

Closes-Bug: #1810401
  (cherry picked from commit 7acca40563ebde1696a95a4ab9f646b754edeeb2)

Change-Id: Ibd1ff419d13cace906d4cd9765dc7b5486bc19a7

commit_message:
add get_pci_request_from_vif to request.py

- This change adds a new function that creates an
  InstancePCIRequest object from a nova VIF object

- The interface accepts an optional numa_policy for
  The allcoations. Currently all sriov pci requests
  can only have the legacy policy. As such this is
  the default policy used but it is expected that
  other policies will be supproted in the future.

- This new function is not currently used but will
  be invoked by follow up patches to enable sriov
  live migration. This will be called in
  check_can_live_migrate_destination to create the
  set of pci request that will be claimed on the
  destination node prior to live migrating.

Change-Id: I06d03eb9545cd786a019b2903a742b6aa011ce45
Partial-Implements: blueprint libvirt-neutron-sriov-livemigration
Co-Authored-By: Adrian Chiris <adrianc@mellanox.com>

subject: Experimental component for a JSON data model
messages:
[{'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-11-07 06:11:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-11-08 02:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-11-18 23:00:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Thanks for the feedback in IRC meeting! I'll reflect more on them and amend the spec with more detailed justification or a different approach."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-11-21 02:10:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-11-21 02:34:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Added more details to shed more light on some of the concerns raised during the IRC meeting.

Also noting that while everyone is welcome to help, I expect that I can do the implementation myself so as to not drain dev resources from Congress main.

Thanks again for the discussions!'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-11-29 03:12:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-11-29 03:14:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

minor revision to the yaml file format. still ready for review.'}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-12-11 09:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I agree on the analysis of the problem but I think there are alternative less disturbing solutions.

I may be wrong, but I think that postgresql jsonb just mixes a way to access json data - the ->> -@> operators - and regular SQL. Tables are implicit but somehow exist if you separate the two parts. 

Another approach would be to have an explicit way of declaring tables with json accessors and keeping the back-ends as they are. I would look at something like jmespath (http://jmespath.org/) for this. If we follow this route, we can also have the same approach for the old fashioned xml datasource with xpath.

It does not solve how often or how we query datasources, but I am not sure the postgresql version handles it more transparently.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-12-12 06:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Thank you Pierre!

I think we agree that there are two main approaches:
One-layer: Write policy directly on source data.
Two-layer: Convert to tables on ingest, then write policy on table data.

I think both approaches are worth pursuing.

In a two-layer approach, a super-admin would need to design the new schema to represent the information and define the translation, and one or more admins would write the policy based on the schema defined by the super-admin. (Obviously super-admin and admin could be the same person.)

For concreteness let's take a simple example of Nova server metadata:

We need to convert data like this:
[
   {
      "id":"a",
      "user_id":"ua",
      "status":"ACTIVE",
      "metadata":{
         "property1":1,
         "property2":2
      },
      "image":{
         "id":"ia",
         "links":[
            {
               "href":"http://openstack.example.com/6f70656e737461636b20342065766572/images/70a599e0-31e7-49b7-b260-868f441e862b",
               "rel":"bookmark"
            }
         ]
      }
   },
   {
      "id":"b",
      "user_id":"ub",
      "status":"ACTIVE",
      "metadata":{
         "property1":3,
         "property2":4
      },
      "image":{
         "id":"ib",
         "links":[
            {
               "href":"http://openstack.example.com/6f70656e737461636b20342065766572/images/70a599e0-31e7-49b7-b260-868f441e862b",
               "rel":"bookmark"
            }
         ]
      }
   }
]

Into the following tables:
servers:
id  |  user_id  | status  |  image_id
-------------------------------------
a   |  ua       | ACTIVE  |  ia
b   |  ub       | ACTIVE  |  ib

servers_meta_data:
server_id  |  property  |  value
--------------------------------------
a          |  property1 |  1
a          |  property2 |  2
b          |  property1 |  3
b          |  property2 |  4

A two-layer approach involves the following complexities:
1. It requires the design of a new schema to represent the information. It may seem simple but many schema design decisions need to be made based on an understanding of the data.

Even in the simple example above. The schema designer makes the following decisions:
a. Omit the the image links information because it is available from another source or not useful.
b. The "image" -> "id" property is uniform. Therefore, we can made the "image_id" a column.
c. Unlike "image" -> "id", the properties under "metadata" are probably not uniform. Therefore, they should not be used as column names. Instead, we need to invent a new column name "property" in the servers_meta_data table to store that information.
d. In relating the servers_meta_data information to the server, "id" rather than any of the other top level properties is the key to use. In some cases, the designer must recognize that it takes a combination of properties to form a key. There are even cases when no key exists and a different schema design is needed because of that (handled by the 'id-col' in Congress translator.)

2. No matter the formalism used to define the translation, there is a fundamental complexity in translating hierarchical data to flat tables. jmespath is nice, but it doesn't reduce the fundamental complexity [1].

3. Having an additional schema layer introduces operational complexity. Inevitably, the schema design will not be perfect and will need to be revised over time. In the case of schema revision, either existing policies would need to be migrated or clunky compromises need to be made in the schema design to be backward-compatible. This is especially a problem when mulitple parties write policies on the same data.

4. Having an additional schema layer means policy writers (admins) need to learn the schema, which needs to be documented. (What does a particular column name mean? What are the range of values to expect?). Compare to a one-layer approach where everyone can refer directly to the source data format (API documentation) to know exactly what to expect. This is especially true in the new wave of applications using Swagger/OpenAPI.

All in all, I think it is worthwhile making the two-layer approach available to operators. The problems with of long turn-around for new data is lessened because it essentially allows a super-admin to take the place of the upstream developer.

Along side that, I think it's important for us to at least put one toe in the one-layer approach which completely sidesteps the problem in a simple model. That's why I'm proposing an experimental repo to further explore and refine that approach.

[1] For example, the seemingly simple flatten operation in jmespath is too simple to handle the translation needs. The flatten operation merges sublist items to the parent lists (http://jmespath.org/specification.html#flatten). As seen in the case of Nova server metadata, what we need is more complex (handled by parent-key and vdict subtranslator in Congress). jmespath or not, the complexity is there.'}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-12-12 17:27:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I am not sure that we should look for one single view of a datasource delivered by a super admin as we have today when they are pre-defined
by the developers. Tables should be defined in each theory for the needs of the theory. In fact, this is what you have implicitly with jsonb.

I agree that json query languages limitations can be quite frustrating and jmespath is just an example. jsoniq which is based on the experience of xquery/xpath would be a much better fit : it names each layer of exploration so that you can refer to the server id while exploring the metadata, it can also retrieve keys of an element and access the associated value at the same time.

The main problem is its support as a python library and the fact that it is probably too powerful (you can express join which is not the purpose of a data extractor).'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-12-13 06:52:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Thanks for the helpful discussion Pierre!

Ah I see yes I think targeted extraction from source data into table as needed is much better. I think that vision turns out to be close to what I was thinking here [1], except that postgres is used instead of jsoniq.

Comparing postgres to jsoniq in this approach:
1. I think the postgres language and formalism is a better fit than jsoniq for extracting data into tables because postgres natively understands tables, with column names and column types etc.
With jsoniq, it can be done but seems to require more retrofitting. The end result is more work for developers, more fragile integration, and more complexity for users. For example, using jsoniq a user may end up writing a query that for some data would end up producing rows of different lengths. The problem may appear down the road (as new data come in) and cause serious confusion.

2. jsoniq is fairly supported, but postgres has a big advantage in user/developer base and community support.

3. jsoniq (say zorba vm with python binding) requires building from source. postgres is packaged with linux distros.

4. zorba could be somewhat more efficient than postgres for doing the translation, but I expect the difference is not huge especially because in this case we can configure postgres without data durability.

Considering all this, to me it makes sense to first create the congress-postgres service (very simple code; it took me a couple days to make a prototype), evaluate and refine in practice to see whether postgres works as well as I expect from my testing. If it proves successful, then we can decide to build the integration to make congress-postgres serve as data extraction tool for congress. If postgres turns out to be a bad choice, then we can decide to kill it and try a different approach, perhaps zorba/jsoniq.

One thought is that instead of a separate repo, we could make the proposed service an experimental component in existing code. Initially it would be fairly independent from the other components, but if we decide to use it as the data extraction tool, then we'll integrate it into the pub-sub system."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-12-14 00:17:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-12-14 00:17:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Updated to propose an experimental component rather than an experimental repo.'}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-12-19 16:35:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Ok Let us try it as it is.

Another argument against the technical choice as a long term solution is that it makes Congress dependent on Postgres. Postgres is supported by Openstack but it is rarely the deployed choice. So for operational deployments, it means a new database just for Congress with eventually all the operational cost of maintaining a database.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-12-19 19:52:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Good point, Pierre.

My hope is that the operational overhead will be acceptable because the postgres database is essentially disposable. Congress can recreate it whenever needed. One deployment model could be postgres docker on ramdisk whose lifecycle is tied to Congress.

As mentioned in the proposal, we're not wedded to postgres, but simply starting our experimentation there. Embedded solutions can also be explored."}, {'account_id': 25553, 'date': '2019-01-08 02:26:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11278, 'date': '2019-01-09 08:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2019-01-09 17:53:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thank you all for the reviews!'}]

commit_message:
Experimental component for a JSON data model

The translation from JSON source data to tabular Congress data places the
limited resources of Congress developers in the way of the Congress users
having the flexibility to quickly try/use any data source and data field as
the need arises in their policy use cases. This spec is a proposal to
experiment with removing the translation step, thus retaining the source JSON
data model, as a promising way to overcome the limitation.

Change-Id: I9838e4bfb051fb8d9e1e83920e2253e1d6495ab7

The registered limits in keystone require a system scoped token to
work. Getting one of those requires that domain and project information
are not set.

Change-Id: I2e1640e9f9ef6cdf56bef49d1ae8f0591570c3e6
'}, {'created': '2019-01-08 23:26:20.000000000', 'message': 'Add devstack-system-admin for system scoped actions

work. Getting one of those requires that domain and project information
are not set.

Change-Id: I2e1640e9f9ef6cdf56bef49d1ae8f0591570c3e6
'}]
commit_message:
Add devstack-system-admin for system scoped actions

Keystone is moving more things to require a system scoped token to
work. Getting one of those requires that domain and project information
are not set.

Change-Id: I2e1640e9f9ef6cdf56bef49d1ae8f0591570c3e6

commit_message:
WIP: Add ability to process asynchronous events

It adds a generic way to process events for any node interface,
and also event processor for neutron network interface as
reference implementation.

Story: 1304673
Task: 10236
Co-Authored-By: Vasyl Saienko <vsaienko@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I8073d9b337ea2ba746b2cca06fd699871bed3300

subject: Enable native handlers for neutron API operations
messages:
[{'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-02 22:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-03 00:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-01-03 11:32:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Doug, thank you for raising this bug and proposing this fix.  I don't think I'm fully understanding it yet, though, and I wonder if you could help me with that.

Firstly, regarding the effect of setting __native_bulk_support, I see this code in neutron/api/v2/base.py:

    def _is_native_bulk_supported(self):
        native_bulk_attr_name = ("_%s__native_bulk_support"
                                 % self._plugin.__class__.__name__)
        return getattr(self._plugin, native_bulk_attr_name, False)

But it seems to me that that needs a different attr name than __native_bulk_support, right?  I can't see anywhere that the __native_bulk_support name (precisely) will make a difference...

Secondly, I believe the intent is that Neutron ends up calling XXX_bulk() methods in the ML2 plugin code, instead of looping over a non-bulk method.  But exactly which XXX_bulk() methods do you have in mind here?  Specifically, in neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py I see create_network_bulk, create_port_bulk and create_subnet_bulk, but I don't see any bulk methods for security groups...'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-03 16:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Doug, thank you for raising this bug and proposing this fix.  I
 > don't think I'm fully understanding it yet, though, and I wonder if
 > you could help me with that.
 > 
 > Firstly, regarding the effect of setting __native_bulk_support, I
 > see this code in neutron/api/v2/base.py:
 > 
 > def _is_native_bulk_supported(self):
 > native_bulk_attr_name = ("_%s__native_bulk_support"
 > % self._plugin.__class__.__name__)
 > return getattr(self._plugin, native_bulk_attr_name, False)
 > 
 > But it seems to me that that needs a different attr name than
 > __native_bulk_support, right?  I can't see anywhere that the
 > __native_bulk_support name (precisely) will make a difference...
 > 
 > Secondly, I believe the intent is that Neutron ends up calling
 > XXX_bulk() methods in the ML2 plugin code, instead of looping over
 > a non-bulk method.  But exactly which XXX_bulk() methods do you
 > have in mind here?  Specifically, in neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py
 > I see create_network_bulk, create_port_bulk and create_subnet_bulk,
 > but I don't see any bulk methods for security groups...

Hi, and thanks for looking! It mangles it with class in that check, as you can see in this debug output:

server.log.1.gz:2019-01-02 22:25:37.069 44087 INFO neutron.api.v2.base [-] checking for native bulk support for _CalicoPlugin__native_bulk_support
server.log.1.gz:2019-01-02 22:25:37.069 44087 INFO neutron.api.v2.base [-] bulk support check is False

And after this change:

server.log.1.gz:2019-01-02 23:47:46.326 118879 INFO neutron.api.v2.base [-] checking for native bulk support for _CalicoPlugin__native_bulk_support
server.log.1.gz:2019-01-02 23:47:46.326 118879 INFO neutron.api.v2.base [-] bulk support check is True

The ml2 plugin inherits the various db mixins, so it pulls in the _bulk routines in neutron/db/* as well, so look in neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py

I think all of the following non-inheritable toggles should be set for all newer plugins, but I only had time to test the bulk one with the calico core plugin:

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py#L146-L155'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-08 17:46:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-01-08 18:01:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-08 19:02:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-01-09 10:20:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks Doug; I understand the mechanism now.  It was the Python name mangling that I was previously unaware of, so thanks for pointing me to that.

Now just making sure I understand what pagination and sorting do...'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-01-09 10:38:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-09 15:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-09 15:51:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-01-09 15:52:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Enable native handlers for neutron API operations

Since this plugin inherits from the ml2 plugin, make use of
the native bulk, paging, and sorting handlers.

Closes-bug: 1810350
Change-Id: Id2deeea9b6722f8282b0f5fe478b4470e76c675e

commit_message:
Look for lower-case hostname when adding to ssh_known_hosts

We need to normalize hostnames to lower-case in order to avoid
case discrepancies.

Change-Id: Iaf73f9ae346425881e70500cf3ee28599fc4171a
Partial-Bug: 1809273
(cherry picked from commit c71d234bf8a4a9f23ace6a29ebc570c390a2f7b3)

subject: Add dumb-init package
messages:
[{'account_id': 24580, 'date': '2019-01-08 21:10:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-01-09 17:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think it would be better if this was submitted to OSH image building instead.'}, {'account_id': 24580, 'date': '2019-01-09 17:33:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

yes agreed.'}, {'account_id': 24580, 'date': '2019-01-09 17:34:28.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

make the change in osh loci build script because neutron image doesn't need the dumb-init in general except by the osh ingress-vip chart."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-08 21:10:26.000000000', 'message': 'Add dumb-init package

Openstack helm ingress-vip container which uses the Neutron image fails to
deploy due to missing dumb-init binary. Another issue is that even with
this patch, the binary is installed to /var/lib/openstack/bin instead of
/usr/bin.

Change-Id: I092e9ca562f312608674270e22fe2ec67c2a3b6f
'}]
commit_message:
Add dumb-init package

Openstack helm ingress-vip container which uses the Neutron image fails to
deploy due to missing dumb-init binary. Another issue is that even with
this patch, the binary is installed to /var/lib/openstack/bin instead of
/usr/bin.

commit_message:
[DNM] stub out sriov live migration

- This is a placeholder patch to track
  what is requried to enable sriov
  live migration.
- This wil be the last patch in supporting
  sriov live migration
- This can be ignored for now as it is
  just for tracking what work i still need
  to do in code.

Change-Id: I2e6995aaae1878740f1d9459c7e67b0cbac0d03a
implements: bp/libvirt-neutron-sriov-livemigration

commit_message:
Directly source ML2 plugin for devstack

Source the plugin so we can directly invoke the ml2 helper methods
without loading neutron-legacy devstack code which we do by using
the q-* service names.

This enables migration to the neutron-* service names to occur.

Change-Id: Ia10839f36a240a503eb4b673a4e39105f1c6abb5

Stop running grenade-py3

of resources.

commit_message:
No longer expect releases of django_openstack_auth

django_openstack_auth's function was merged into other deliverables,
so it is no longer released, but the repository is still kept
around for maintained branches.

Mark it as release-management:deprecated so that we no longer
expect (or track the absence of) any release for it.

Change-Id: I5c98446c6ba9c745e30ff3f1ab0485b1a8154dd1
